urn:contentItem:5TSR-P0C1-DXM4-G3XR-00000-00Survey: Most health informatics executives see ‘big tech' as a threat2018-11-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:39ZLexisNexisARTICLESurvey: Most health informatics executives see ‘big tech' as a threatEvan Sweeney

Seven in 10 health IT executives are “somewhat concerned” about technology companies like Google, Amazon and Apple encroaching into the healthcare space. Many see the consumer tech giants pushing health systems toward price transparency faster than they want to go.

Healthcare informatics executives are feeling a pinch of anxiety heading into next year thanks to a growing interest in healthcare from the world's foremost technology companies.

Seven in 10 health IT executives are “somewhat concerned” about technology companies like Google, Amazon and Apple encroaching into the healthcare space, according to a new surveyby the Center for Connected Medicine, jointly operated by GE Healthcare, Nokia and the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center.

Quantitative and qualitative polls conducted over the course of several months focused on informatics leaders in the C-suite, including chief informatics officers, chief medical informatics officers and chief nursing informatics officers spanning nearly 40 health systems.

RELATED: Jamie Dimon: Amazon, Berkshire partnership ‘pissed off' healthcare companies

Just 17% of respondents said they were not worried at all about "big tech” companies entering the healthcare space, while 10% said they were very concerned. That aligns with comments from JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon that the bank's healthcare venture with Amazon and Berkshire Hathaway “pissed off” some healthcare executives.

Those concerns revolved primarily around the ability of those companies to offer a better consumer experience, according to the report.

“The biggest threat is if these companies get between us and the end consumer,” one CEO said. “If there is a platform regulated and controlled by someone other than us—that makes us nervous."

Others said the technology companies would force price transparency faster than incumbent health systems are willing to go, which some executives say could lead to confusion among consumers. Of course, patient advocates have long pushed for broader transparency in healthcare where prices for one procedure can vary wildly from one hospital to the next.

RELATED: Hospitals aren't the only ones with price variation. New research shows payers have large discrepancies, too

Some executives, however, highlighted new partnership opportunities with the tech companies, particularly in the supply chain. A survey earlier this year found that the majority of healthcare executives believe Amazon can live up to its hype in that regard.

Broadly, there is a subtle shift in priorities for the nation's top health IT executives. Cybersecurity remains top of mind for health systems, but more established technology challenges have bubbled back to the surface. Heading into 2019 survey respondents said telehealth and interoperability were top of mind, in addition to cybersecurity, replacing predictive analytics and consumer-facing technology in last year's survey.

Cybersecurity is the lone stalwart. Nearly 90% of respondents said they expect to increase their cyber budgets in 2019, and half of those said the increase would be greater than 5%. Just 20% said they were “very confident” in their IT recovery and business continuity plans, and most executives still see staff as the biggest target, with spearphishing campaigns as the most pervasive challenge.

“The people that are up to no good have far better tools than we do on our platforms,” one CEO said. “If they really target you, they will likely find a way in.”

TheStreet.com publishes selected email received by the publication and its staff members. To send an email intended for publication in this section, email letters@thestreet.com and include your full name and city. Letters may be edited for length, style, clarity and accuracy. Market Insana-ty 

Jim Cramer, Is it coincidence? Ron Insana in London and the markets boom upward. Maybe I'll have to try to find out who his travel agent is, and tie that into a trading package. My only question is, when is he due back? Great coverage today. Thank you! 

-- Scott Eadie (received 6/17/98) Buying and Holding 

James Cramer: Please don't give in to the buy and holders. I am a 25-year-old equities trader at a midsize limited partnership and the next best source of knowledge away from the desk is your writing. Your daily synopsis of what you see going on helps me more than any news channel or site. 

-- Ed McCabe (received 6/16/98) Too Much Support? 

James Cramer: It seems to me that support levels and trend lines are meant to be broken. Dell, Costco, Safeway, AOL, Lucent are all leaders and are all under attack daily, yet they haven't cracked their support levels. Until they do and the towel is thrown into the ring, will we really have the capitulation that is so often talked about? 

-- Frank Degley (received 6/16/98) Battling the Market 

Gary B. Smith, I can certainly appreciate the scientific approach to trading. Cramer, however, seems to prefer military history. His columns are replete with references to such well-known traders as Robert E. Lee and Erich Ludendorff. I can imagine Cramer humming martial tunes as he orders his funds into battle. When he feels Napoleonic, there's always La Marseillaise. (When he wants to be Hannibal, he'd have to make up his songs from the Punic Wars.) Perhaps you should include history in the trading curriculum. The battlefields may differ, but the tactics may be the same. 

-- Eugene Finerman (received 6/15/98) Dismal Business 

Dunlap's departure brings to mind the Buffett observation that when a guy with a reputation for excellence goes into a dismal business, it's the reputation of the business that survives. 

-- George Acton (received 6/15/98) Speech Reviews 

James Cramer: Just wanted to say, thanks for sharing the history and future strategy. 

-- Matt Bayly (received 6/15/98) 

James Cramer: Needless to say I'm glad, to say the least, that you let TSC live. I will only be able to retire at a reasonable age if I invest. To learn that I joined TSC. Thanks Jim, Dave Kansas, and the whole crew for the education. 

-- Thomas J. Reich (received 6/14/98) 

James Cramer: I am so happy you decided to continue with TSC. If I had known you were thinking about quitting, I would have gotten on a plane, flown there and tried to talk you out of it. 

-- Jeanne Merchant (received 6/14/98) 

James Cramer: Your one weakness is charging monthly subscription rates. Once you are comfortably above break even, the monthly rate should go to $0 or at least go down significantly. The number of subscribers will mushroom. 

-- George Seay (received 6/14/98) 

James Cramer: It was interesting and refreshing to read the "story" of TheStreet.com and understand your vision for the site. As a new "Home Depot do-it-yourself" investor I look to the site for daily information, direction, and insight to help me make informed financial decisions. While it is important for people to understand your vision, admiration, and zest to make TheStreet.com the absolute best source for market and financial information I think it is more important for those sentiments to be echoed by your readers and for that I say kudos! 

-- Matthew Shapiro (received 6/14/98) Axing the Chainsaw 

James Cramer: You were smart to unload Sunbeam. I think Michael Price wishes he had unloaded Al Dunlap sooner. Dunlap represents the dark side of American business. It takes no particular talent to take over the management of a business, fire half the payroll to produce a couple of good quarters and leave the business smoldering in your wake while you take off to "turn around" another company. 

-- Mark W. Zabell (received 6/15/98) Spots Be Gone 

Jesse Eisinger: Interesting story on Dusa. I had the kerotosis on the backs of both hands. At the doctor's office, they zapped each spot with each with a spray of liquid nitrogen. Just an instant of pain, like a pin prick. No further pain, quick healing, no scarring. Good luck Dusa. 

-- Jeffrey Warren (received 6/14/98) The Bottom 

James Cramer: In your recent column, you mentioned you have a way of spotting the bottom in a stock. Since many of us are trying to identify the bottom in many of our favorite stocks, how about a column detailing your methodology. You could frame it around some past experiences. 

-- Jonathan Daws (received 6/12/98) Eyes Peeled 

James Cramer: Thanks for your honest appraisal of Rowan and the oil services in general. I am currently long NE and have been keeping me eyes peeled for comments from you on the subject. I certainly value your opinion and this oil correction has been a real learing experience for me. I am not a trader (obviously), but I also hate loosing money. Your insight in this area has been quite helpful and look forward to your ongoing commentary. No flames from me. 

-- Brian Fryar (received 6/12/98) Nicely Adjusted 

James Cramer: I think your columns this week have been nicely adjusted to state not only that value matters, but also to give specific company examples. 

Almost everyone at my office uses the "it has gone down, now it must go up" method and then they give themselves a pat on the back for doing so much research. 

If we have a long bear, they will all leave, muttering that the market is not to be trusted. Will the 1980 attitude then prevail all over again? 

-- Bob Morgen (received 6/12/98) Giving Up Hope 

James Cramer: Your comparison of Techs to oil drillers was an eye opening slap in the face. And in my case it was probably a much needed slap in the face. I'm a big tech fan (tech investing has been so good to me over the past two years), but as your column pointed out to me -- my trading lately has been based more on hope then on strategy and discipline. 

Thanks for getting me pointed in the right direction again. 

-- Jason Winfrey (received 6/11/98) Good Advice 

Gary B. Smith: Your GBS Training System column was the best online trading advice I've read. Period. 

I'm a retired musician, and unfortunately, not a math whiz, so when I tackle projects like writing spreadsheets, writing/running backtests, keeping paper-trading portfolios for bottom-fishing/shorting data, keeping a trading diary, etc....it's out of the greatest reluctance that I begin these daunting chores, let alone maintain them… 

But you're darn right......the "zen" is bunk, and I *intuitively* KNEW that....I just never wanted to admit it to myself, because......hey......If I could just guess "up" or "down" right, and get "in sync" with the psychology, and be a "contrarian" trader, and blah, blah, blah.....BALONEY!!! 

I've been at this for longer than I care to admit, and your article really has me soul searching...… 

I really hope you'll concentrate on this theme Gary, and develop the idea with guys like me in mind........even if it's nothing more than a step by step glimpse of how you came by the conclusion to "buy at market" at the open, instead of gap-open techniques with limit orders… (Did you keep records of the actual fill, vs a paper trade fill and backtest it?) And do you trade on days that open down like today ? with trend or against ? 

You know, the works ! All the details.....not necessarily to copy, but to inspire innovation. 

I don't know *anyone* else that's doing this; to the contrary, most "trading" sights are strictly "wing and a prayer" outfits, where the "main guy" makes a trade recommendation, and all the unfortunates within his earshot, bid up his _already-filled_ order, getting at least ONE person out with a profit. (I wish I had a nickel for every one of these I've seen.....GAH!) 

Your column is terrific, and I hope you have the editorial freedom to go so far as to suggest that we collectively get off our bums, fire the newsletter/website/cnbc/aol gurus, start converting our mistakes to data that we can learn from, like you seem to have done. 

-- Dick London (received 6/11/98) The Intel Probe 

James Cramer: First, let me say that I strongly agree with you regarding the undue influence of lawyers, and other non-productive varmints, especially as it relates to distractions for companies like Intel. Second, I agree that Intel is a great company, and they have made me a lot of money through the years, and I love their products and the speed with which they evolve. 

However, I must respectfully disagree with you that there is absolutely no anti-trust issue with respect to Intel. Sadly, they have been guilty of some tactics similar to those of MSFT in recent times since they have controlled the PC hardware. For example, they were requiring that if a PC vendor wanted to have early system design info for each new generation of microprocessor chip, they had to use Intel motherboards (not ONLY microprocessors) in their first generation machines. Now, if there had been a reasonable alternative source of microprocessors, this might have been reasonable, but, of course, they had a functional monopoly. In an industry that moves as fast as the PC business, this of course meant that ALL first versions of a particular generation were on Intel motherboards, thereby precluding innovation by the PC vendor themselves. Or, if a vendor tried to go it alone, they would not be able to have a competitive product available during the critical first months of a new generation, which would have been tantamount to commercial suicide. 

There are other examples, as well--things such as Intel customers suddenly suffering parts shortages should they agree to use chips from an Intel competitor. 

Having said all this, I actually feel that this current investigation is probably good for INTC. At the very least,it will cause them to reassess their business practices, and (if they are still doing this sort of stuff) change in ways that are better for us, their customers. Given that Messrs. Barrett et al. are much less likely to take the arrogant approach of Mr. Softee, I would not be surprised to see a reasonable settlement that will be an obvious winner for everyone. 

-- Dave Kisker (received 6/11/98) Leave the Crash Helmet 

The waves of "impending crash" caveats that accompany just about every discussion of the U.S. stockmarket caused me to recall a sage's advice that, "the market always does what the fewest people expect". Well, there are certainly many people who expect a crash, but there are also a lot of people who believe the market is headed much higher. Is there another scenario that might be developing? I believe so. 

First, lets think about the economic background that investors face. The Asian economies have yet to find a bottom. Several of our telecom equipment analysts have indicated that the companies they follow should report in line second quarter results, but that companies that distribute to Asia (the manufacturer's customers) are experiencing large increases in inventory. Result: channel stuffing will enable many companies to hit June quarter forecasts, but second half forecasts will come down. If this is true, it explains why it seems that there have been a manageable number of pre-releases this quarter. Nonetheless, the conference calls may be a different matter. Conclusion: Domestic U.S. economic growth is unlikely to accelerate and should begin to slow as the year progresses. If so, inflation will be very low and with it, bond yields will decline. 

If the market does what the fewest expect, what could this scenario mean for investors? 

1. Continued high valuations (P/E, Price/Book, etc.). This will drive the valuation crowd crazy. Investors will scramble for anything with growth among a diminishing list of growth companies. This view helps explain the high valuations of internet stocks --- at least they have growth. 

2. Volatile individual stock prices. These high valuations will cause companies that disappoint to be slaughtered because confidence in future growth will be shaken (and investors will move quickly to the next hot growth story). 

3. Slowing growth, high valuations and periodic blowups will depress the typical investor's annual returns into the mid-single digits. Few individuals or money managers will be able to sprint through an investment landscape increasingly littered with landmines. 

4. Low bond yields will cause total returns from fixed income instruments to be less than 6%. Although the long bond might have a bit of price upside as yields drift toward 5%, total returns elsewhere along the yield curve won't provide double digit returns. 

Bottom line: Investors may get neither mid-teens returns nor a crash that enables them to buy on the dip. Instead, we may be headed for a several quarter period of sluggish performance as valuations gradually come back to more normal levels. As a old consumer goods analyst, this is exactly how large cap consumer stocks behave --- a few to several years of outstanding performance, followed not by a crash, but by flat line price performance as valuations catch up (take a look at KO in the late 1980's/early 1990's, or WMT more recently). 

-- Richard Davis Jr. (received 6/11/98) Hayden's an Asset 

An asset allocator is a welcome addition to TheStreet.com. I'd like to see a debate between Cramer and Vern Hayden on whether asset allocation maximizes returns or guarantees mediocrity. 

-- Roger Mann (received 6/10/98) Rewarded 

The only people who have been rewarded by the R.S. Contrarian Fund are those of us who were smart enough to get out last October when it was first nominated for the fund graveyard. Thanks TSC. Paul Stephens doesn't have a clue!!! 

-- Jim Puffer (received 6/9/98) Y2K, Revisited 

The article on E*Trade and Y2K is very interesting, but not necessarily accurate. Many non-legacy systems, built in the past couple of years, are still non-Y2K compliant. I know first hand of one bank in the Northeast, which shall remain nameless, that contract to have a new system built to keep track of its trading. They engage a consulting firm, which built the system totally with 2-digit dates. 

Webtrends 3.5, a program that I use to analyze my web site, is not Y2K compliant. This is not only not a legacy system, it is very recent and totally Internet oriented 

This is not to say that E*Trade is not Y2K compliant, I'm simply pointing out that just because it is "Internet" and "recent" doesn't make it Y2K compliant. Given the legacy systems it must interface with, they could very easily have Y2K issues. The article doesn't mention any statements from the company about Y2K. 

Overall, the securities industry is far ahead of just about any other industry in terms of awareness and progress. The initial SIA testing is scheduled for this July, and their testing methodology is available on the Internet. 

-- Jeff Jacobs (received 6/9/98) Perplexed 

I am still perplexed by Jim Cramer's characterization of his stock positions as "inventory". As near as I can ascertain, Cramer has long term opinions about the unfolding relative improvement of certain large companies. He believes that on a short term basis the markets in those stocks reach technically diifficult to sustain short term levels of excess enthusiasm or revulsion. His trading, therefore, is broadly "fading" the public order flow. 

This is not, however, what I think of as securities "inventory", which is the raw material of a truly market-making function, or the by-product of the distribution of new issues. 

In my experience, one of the most dangerous situations a trader can find himself in is confusing speculation with a market-making discipline. It often leads to a two sets of books mentality where the interim losses are consigned to a mental investment account and the mental market-making account feels great. 

Mr. Cramer's frenetic trading may be wonderfully cathartic for his hedge fund's senior partner; but one wonders at the end of the day, how much does it add to the performance of the firm's underlying, and presumably carefully formulated bets? Is it in large part grist for the insatiable moloch of Wall Street entertainment against a twice daily TheStreet deadline? 

-- Paul J. Isaac (received 6/8/98) The Ax 

Eric Moskowitz: Good series of articles on the various axes' on the Street. However, it is at times difficult to keep an eye out for comments from these analysts on a daily basis when the news agencies that report analysts upgrades/downgrades don't identify the analysts as "axes". Therefore, how about you guys putting out a "The Axe Has Spoken" column as soon as one of these analysts makes a change in recommendation. 

-- Brett Rule (received 6/5/98) New Fan 

Herb Greenberg: Regarding the recent discussion in your column about comments directed at JJC, I offer my 2 cents. First, I began reading TSC because of JJC. I subscribed for a year (and will continue for long after that, I suppose) because of JJC. I try to read everything he writes, whether in TSC or other venues. I have learned more from him about trading than could be bought at any price at any of this country's best b-schools. I am obviously an ardent fan of his. 

That said, I am also becoming an ardent fan of yours since your arrival at TSC. Perhaps it is the lawyer in me, but I like seeing the issues from "both sides of the street." It allows one to keep a clearer head, and that is what the entire exercise of TSC should be about. The "sniping" is taken for what it is: the good-natured ribbing of JJC from one who also admires his work and personna, while making valid points in disagreement. As I've said to you before, keep up the good work. 

-- Bill Luttrell (received 6/5/98) More Helpful 

Herb Greenberg: If you stop offering your perspective on the market, I'll cancel. Although I respect JJC, and his views re trading etc. are interesting, your columns are much more helpful in my effort to understand this market as an investor. So much noise and confusion out there! What we need is wisdom and perspective on things. That's why I read your columns and that's why I'm still a subscriber to TSC. 

-- Tim Mikkel (received 6/5/98) Fore 

James Cramer: When people hassle you about [a recent column on] Dell here is another analogy that my explain your bullishness. 

The four best golfers at a private club are Mr. Dell, Mr. IBM, Mr. Compaq and Mr. HP. They always shoot in the 70's with Mr. Dell usually shooting a couple of strokes better than the rest. There are lots of other members at the club but while being good players, they can't really compete with the big four. The club they belong to is know as an easy course(wide fairways, flat greens, few trees and sand traps). It is easy to score well. This course is the equivalent of the PC industry of the last couple of years, growth being so rapid everyone makes money. 

The big four decide to go on a golf vacation. By some miracle they are able to play Augusta National. Augusta National is the golf equivalent of today's PC environment "HELL". Needless to say Mr. IBM, Mr. Compaq and Mr. HP are completely overmatched by the course and shoot horrible scores. Mr. Dell sucks it up and scrambles his way to to another sub 80 round. Mr. IBM, Mr. Compaq and Mr. HP put on a brave face and say they are going to head to the driving range to make a few adjustments in their game. Things will be better tomorrow. 

The fundamental difference between Mr. Dell and the others(Mr IBM, Mr. Compaq and Mr. HP) is that Mr. Dell can adjust to the rapidly changing environment as the environment changes. Mr. IBM, Mr. Compaq and Mr. HP get annihilated by a change in the environment, go back home reflect on what happened, develop a plan to adapt, put the plan into action and hope things will be better tomorrow. They will always be killed by a negative change in the environment(hard courses) and do well when the environment turns positive(easy courses). 

The morale of the story is that Mr Dell is a better golfer and if your going to bet on Golf then bet on Mr Dell. CREAMer always rises to the top. 

-- Mike Yaffe (received 6/5/98) Kudos 

Herb Greenberg: I don't understand people who don't "get it". I think the ongoing debate between the you [and James Cramer] is one of the things that make TSC an interesting forum. I, for one, am sick and tired of all the whiners who expect this to be a promtional site that has nothing but "buys" and positive spin. Tell them to put on their rose-coloured sunglasses and spend more time at www.justhypeme.com , otherwise known as Silicon Investor. As a paying customer, I would rather see fewer articles written for newbies - your sophistication and expertise is what adds value. 

-- A. John Carlesso (received 6/5/98) Remember the Akron 

Jim Cramer: Enjoy your writing, your comments have made money for me. Thanks, and here is my favorite mental image of trading psychology. Have you ever seen the newsreel clips of the 1920's US Airship Akron disaster? The scene is like traders' thinking about when to take the loss or hold on. The airship was met by a party of about a hundred ground handlers grabbing the ropes when a sudden wind gust and loss of ballast control caused the ship to bob up and down twenty, thirty, forty feet three or four times before rapidly climbing to a thousand feet unable to descend and then crashing within the half hour. There was a rain of falling men from different heights. When does the trader take his loss? Like the ground handler he has to decide if he lets go for a 20 feet fall to suffer a broken leg or hold on for a litte longer until the ship gets back to only to only a 5 foot hop down. One could even hope to get back down uninjured. But then what if the ship just continues up and up… This happened to the ones who didn't let go before it was too late. However, one man did survive by hanging even to a thousand feet holding on for dear life and walked away from the crash landing. 

-- Sanford Friedrich (received 6/5/98) Trust 

James Cramer: I welcomed the wisdom you shared yesterday, it helped put things in perspective and clearly you were right until the market got sand-bagged by the Intel whiff. You are on the money though, the trust level is down - I think that's what I was trying to articulate in my mail yesterday. Why should a trader trust a market that constantly deflates and then only partially re-inflates the next day? Clearly, for a newbie like me it's hard to see why one should - how many times do you need to get your hands burnt before you stop after all? 

Perhaps that's the most frightening thing about the market - the general feeling appears to be falling to short sentiment, which is something I haven't had much experience dealing with (I did send mail to Smith a few weeks ago to go over it since I suspected we would end up in this sort of market sometime - didn't think it would be this quick though). Here we now have people using the chats on the Net to try to move stocks down, not up - perhaps the strongest evidence I've felt that the nature of the game is changing. I sure hope I'm wrong, since this is a game that I really don't look forward to playing in. 

-- Bryan McCormick (received 6/5/98) What Intel Didn't Say 

With everything INTC has already said about business slacking off, coupled with another wave of price cuts, does Intel really need to issue another statement saying its profits/revenue/growth won't be what people thought? 

-- Erik Milstone (received 6/4/98) Turning the Tables 

Since Mr. Cramer has been on CNBC so much, I would like to see him turn the tables and invite Mark Haines to show up for Mr. Cramer's new show, Real Money. Thanks for all the good work. 

-- Tom Delosso (received 6/4/98) Instructive 

James Cramer: I read everything you publish on TS.com and the articles that are most instructive (to me) are the "I Can Screw Up Too" ones where you describe and analyze your mistakes. I too evaluate my mistakes from every angle with the intention of learning how to avoid making the same mistake twice. Please keep it up. 

-- Jerry Daughan, Harpswell, Maine (received 6/4/98) Stretched 

James Cramer: Your arguments seem more stretched by the day. For some reason you don't want to acknowledge that there is a huge slowdown at the semiconductor and boxmaker level. Dell, GTW, may be good trades, but it's ludicrous to suggest that the fundamentals are improving. 

-- Steve Vita (received 6/4/98) No Reply 

Dan Colarusso: I have filed several e-mail type complaints with the NASDR office and the SEC enforcement-tips office over the past few months when I have seen "blatant" volume-spike options trading in calls or puts where there was no news, AND then after hours that company will come out with dramatic 'material' information which causes massive trading in the underlying stock the following morning-open. Some of these instances are so damm obvious that (you or I) figure that the regulators should have been able to see it, also. Most of the time, I never hear back from them. 

-- Gerald E. Naugle, Boulder, Colo. (received 6/4/98) Hear! Hear! 

As regards JJC's motion to start a "conference cancellation watch" on TSC, here's a second. 

-- Tom Scott (received 6/3/98)

urn:contentItem:5W43-JP91-JD33-J0V1-00000-00Sustainability - Drivers And Implications For The Technology Sector2019-05-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:39ZLexisNexisSustainability - Drivers And Implications For The Technology Sector

Sustainability is a growing issue for the Technology sector, with environment, social and governance issues all coming to the fore. Although some consumers are concerned about the impact of electronic waste on the environment - with the widespread use of non-degradable plastic a key focus - the sector is a major contributor to greenhouse gas emissions thanks to rapid growth in power consumption, an issue that does not greatly resonate with consumers. Drivers of change are corporations, which are brand-sensitive and increasingly being scrutinised on performance by investors, while their employees are becoming more empowered to ensure changes in sustainability and good governance are adhered to. Governments - through regulatory bodies - are becoming more involved but are more responsive than proactive.

Key View Sustainability is a growing issue for the Technology sector, with environment, social and governance issues all coming to the fore. Although some consumers are concerned about the impact of electronic waste on the environment - with the widespread use of non-degradable plastic a key focus - the sector is a major contributor to greenhouse gas emissions thanks to rapid growth in power consumption, an issue that does not greatly resonate with consumers. Drivers of change are corporations, which are brand-sensitive and increasingly being scrutinised on performance by investors, while their employees are becoming more empowered to ensure changes in sustainability and good governance are adhered to. Governments - through regulatory bodies - are becoming more involved but are more responsive than proactive. The Telecoms, media and technology (TMT) sector has, over the last decade, become acutely aware of its impact on the environment, on the global social fabric and in the way that industry stakeholders work together.

TMT companies and those they serve are among the biggest consumers of natural or scarce resources (power, land, human productivity/creativity) and they are very sensitive to any changes in how they are perceived and judged in this context.Many TMT industry players subscribe to some form of corporate and social responsibility (CSR) code of conduct, either collectively or through standalone self-developed internal mechanisms. These tend to be quite loose in terms of definitions of standards and grading of those standards but, where these mechanisms have been in place for several years, and where companies are willing to share data, clear improvements in resource consumption, environmental impact and relationships with shareholders, employees and suppliers are generally being recorded.Technological improvements have been a major facilitator for enhanced business sustainability, but the key drivers remain fundamentally driven by underlying business needs: to improve profitability; to protect or augment the value of the company's brand, and; to secure the loyalty of paying customers and investors. New technology - as has so often been the case throughout history - is rarely properly regulated and can be misused by end-users. This is often out of the control of many stakeholders and, in recent years, technology companies in particular have come in for strong criticism over the ways in which their creations - both in real and hypothetical terms - are being used for ill.Drivers For The TMT Sector Consumers Devices The technology sector offers consumers a heady mix of tangible and intangible products, with the former being represented by disposable pieces of technology, such as personal computers, smartphones, TV sets, games consoles and similar types of gadgets. These tangible products have a significant environmental impact, both at the point of manufacture and at the end of life, owing to their high chemical and non-degradable content.A high proportion of the outer shells of these devices consists of non-recyclable plastic, which often goes to landfill at the end of its lifecycle. Meanwhile, the inner workings such as printed circuit boards, cables, microprocessors, touchscreens, etc vary considerably to the extent to which they can be reused.China has become a high-volume producer of generic or 'white label' consumer electronics, selling these at very low prices to low-budget consumers worldwide. Often, these products are designed with little or no consideration to recyclability and have very short lifespans owing to the limitations of cheaply made components.Broadly, there has been little impetus for change from consumers - often from pressure groups such as Greenpeace - as the desire for the newest gadget tends to override any concerns consumers might have about environmental impact. Furthermore, the junking of obsolete equipment typically occurs out of sight and some entrepreneurial businesses have emerged to act as middle-men in the process, incentivising the collection of materials for recycling by offering cash payments for old gadgets such as phones, TV sets and computers as well as media such as CDs and DVDs. Services Intangible products typically take the form of 'services', such as streamed video, instant messaging, remote computing, personal navigation, and so on. Consumers tend to see little connection between a digital service and the environment and so there is no real driver for change in this area.However, where such services have a pronounced social impact (typified by 'social media' platforms such as Facebook, Instagram and Snap), consumers have become very aware - and sensitive - to the way in which their personal data are shared by the platform to its partners as well as to the nature of the content being posted to and hosted on those networks.Revelations that digital services companies have had customers' personal details stolen or that social media platforms have been working with organisations whose ulterior motives include influencing political discourse and thinking have generated hyperbolic media headlines and caused consumer advocacy groups press for change to business models. However, there has been no fall-off in consumer usage of these platforms, diffusing the overall level of concerns by these stakeholders.As noted above, consumers generally do not see a connection between digital services and the environment and this is down to the diffuse and globalised nature of the services sector. Digital services are powered by vast numbers of large computers, all interlinked by a global network of cables, satellites and wireless connections and data are processed in huge computing warehouses, called datacentres. All of these need and consume enormous amounts of power, a very high proportion of which comes from fossil fuels or their derivatives.Popular media, e-commerce and information platforms (for example, Netflix, Amazon and Google) depend on high non-renewable power consumption and few consumers, if any, are cognizant of this fact. Fewer still are prepared to stop using these platforms unless a shift to renewable power is implemented. Yet tech companies - and the datacentre operators on which they rely - are making efforts to use power in a more sustainable fashion, and numerous power supply agreements have been struck with renewable energy companies by tech giants such as Apple and Facebook. In May 2019, several of the largest US-based tech companies called upon their principal power supplier in Northern Virginia (the biggest datacentre hub in the world) to switch from gas-based power generation to solar and wind faster than it had outlined in its latest 10-year investment plan. Their influence is such that it may force a change in the power company's plans, a first for the power sector. Governments/Policy-Makers The technology sector has flourished since the early 1990s, mainly because its development has largely been left to the private sector, where risk appetites are greater and where entrepreneurialism and innovation through failure has trumped investment pragmatism and conservatism.Governments have generally reduced their involvement in the sector (usually through privatisation or public-private investment partnerships) or have withdrawn direct involvement altogether. Yet, in order to capitalise on stakeholders' use of natural or scarce resources, to protect consumers from dominant or weak players, and to influence technological development to suit society's needs, governments have maintained a degree of control through regulation.Regulation is a form of control that can be sector- or product-specific (for example, setting price increase caps on particular services or mandating network build-out milestones), or it may be enforced more generally, for example though controls on mergers or financial accounting.As in most sectors, regulators' and governments' expertise lags far behind technological development and their response is often driven by consumers' and other stakeholders' concerns. Some of these concerns are wholly justified, others are less so and can take the form of ill-informed and judgemental reactions to experimental or immature applications and business models that tech companies - owing to the highly competitive nature of their businesses - might wish to keep opaque. Investors And Employees The TMT sector hosts a broad spectrum of companies, ranging from small start-ups to sprawling multinationals, all with varying shareholder influences and agendas. The largest companies tend to be listed and therefore subjected to the greatest media, public, shareholder and government scrutiny. They must therefore be highly diligent in responding to concerns about their activities and the corresponding impact this may have on their reputations. However, as the Facebook- Cambridge Analytica scandal and numerous other companies' data leaks attest, tech companies' brand reputations are not easily tarnished, let alone destroyed, such is the degree of their entrenchment.Technology, no matter how advanced or simple to use, is a high-risk investment opportunity, subject to retrospective regulation, rapid changes in consumption trends and fluid macroeconomic risk. Successful players are kept aloft by developing and continually refreshing or replacing differentiated or value-added products. In their bid to stay relevant or gain an edge over rivals, some companies may choose to use corporate practices that are unsustainable or improperly account for key transactions.The bursting of the dot-com bubble in 1999/2000 was driven, in part, by unsustainable investment in immature technologies, the acquisitions and mergers of non-viable businesses, and the use of questionable accounting practices that included - amongst many other now-notorious practices - the billing of the entire projected value of multi-year supply deals in the same quarter that deals were brokered.It is no coincidence that the technology sector began employing CSR initiatives as a guideline for responsible investment and profit growth soon after recovery began in earnest in the early 2000s. This increased transparency, bolstered by the accelerated maturity of technology within social, communication, governance and business infrastructures, saw the technology sector become one of the most attractive elements of investors' portfolios for a second time. The societal benefits of new technology are generally considered to outweigh its risks.Microsoft Can Do Better: Energy Credits And Purchase Agreements Mask Slow Progress In Tech Companies' Moves To Sustainable Energy Use

Source: Fitch Solutions Implications For The TMT Sector Consumers Devices As noted earlier, consumers are not well engaged with the environmental cost of continued device replacement, but pressure groups have forced companies - often those under tightening environmental impact rules set by governments - to take steps to ensure that as much of the content of these old devices is recoverable and reusable as possible, including reducing the number of components, miniaturising core elements and designing products with reusability in mind.Retail and shipping packaging is also coming under scrutiny. In January 2019, Samsung Electronics announced that it would start taking steps to replace plastic packaging materials with paper and other environmentally sustainable elements. From the first half of 2019, the packaging used for Samsung's products and accessories - ranging from mobile phones and tablets to home appliances - will be substituted with environmentally sustainable materials like recycled/bio-based plastics and paper. Other vendors have already embarked on this journey; undoubtedly, others will follow in their wake.With regards to end-of-life processes, the industry has seen the value chain expand to include dedicated device harvesters and recyclers; often, these are independent high-street or online-based organisations, but some manufacturers have set up their own end-of-life collection systems. Users are paid for unwanted items and the harvesters sell them back to the tech sector for a modest profit. Some devices are broken down and recycled; others are sold on at low prices to emerging markets, where the latest models are too expensive to buy.In the UK, for example, distributors (including retailers) must provide a system which allows all customers buying new electrical equipment the opportunity to recycle their old items free of charge. Those establishing their own take-back scheme must as a minimum offer all customers buying new electrical equipment free take back of their old electricals on a like-for-like basis. Incentivised by the prospect of cash for unwanted devices, consumers are engaged by this initiative, but they do not necessarily drive it. Services Although it is by no means the only platform to face increased scrutiny, Facebook has become the poster-child for the growing backlash against social media. Most damagingly, it appears to have engaged with a number of organisations that have since been found to have analysed user profiles and usage data to target users with news, advertisements and related content with the intent of swaying political views. While Facebook may not have been aware of its partners' intentions, its inability to carry out due diligence ahead of sharing data with those entities or to take remedial action or accountability after the fact has led to calls for it to either be more tightly regulated or broken up and 'neutered'.In the wake of further negative revelations - including the discovery that Facebook had actively been seeking to aggressively monetise young users - founder Mark Zuckerberg has conceded that the company (and, by extension, the social media sector as a whole) needs to be regulated by an independent authority.While consumers have become more aware and concerned about the social media sector's business practices, they have not stopped using the biggest platforms. Facebook has seen little fall-off in daily usage rates and other platforms are similarly continuing to do brisk business despite well reported instances of hacking and the hosting of unpalatable content. It is difficult to conceive the scale of a breach of trust that would cause users to drop away in significant numbers.Estimated Value Of Raw Materials In E-Waste, 2016

Calls for Facebook and YouTube to become more accountable for content hosted on their global networks are being listened to by liberal governments or being acted upon (ironically, pre- emptive bans or neutering is something that more authoritarian or socially controlled states have come to excel at).Several Middle East nations have long imposed blanket bans on social media platforms in order to protect both national security and citizens' morals, while countries such as China and Russia have sunk such deep content filters into local Internet infrastructures that they are effectively creating localised and isolated Internets.Liberal countries are also taking steps to protect citizens from harmful 'content'. In July 2019, as part of its Digital Economy Act, the UK will introduce age verification for 'adult content' sites hosted by UK Internet service providers ( ISPs) in an effort to prevent children accidentally accessing pornography. While well-intentioned, potential flaws in the initiative include legitimate users moving onto insecure platforms (raising cybersecurity risks), content moving onto more generic platforms such as social media, unintended blocking of non-pornographic sites, a heightened risk that a newly-created database for registered users could be hacked, and placing the burden of regulation onto an ill-equipped agency (the British Board of Film Classification).Furthermore, mindful that the emergence of a global Internet of Things ( IoT) will see billions of connected devices go live over the next decade, some regulators are looking to ensure that no single technology company can dominate the market from one end to another. In February 2018, French telecoms regulator Arcep said it was looking to create a new framework to ensure the Internet remains open end-to-end, adding the principles of device- or platform- neutrality to the already-regulated principle of net neutrality. Arcep believes the lack of openness of devices, through the use of applications, and its domination by a few major operating systems pose a threat to consumer choice, which must be addressed.Questions are also being asked of global technology players - such as Google - regarding their revenue accounting and tax payment methodologies. In October 2018, the UK government announced a new Digital Services Tax from 2020, targeting Internet companies. The tax will raise GBP275mn in the first year, increasing to GBP440mn in 2023-2024.UK Vs Europe: Digital Services Taxes

Source: UK Government, European Commission, Fitch Solutions The initiative attempts to create a fairer system of taxation for digital players, which have been using legal ways to decrease the amount of taxes they pay in certain European markets. As the tax system still relies on physical presence, it means they were paying less than comparable or smaller companies. The UK is - along with Spain - the first market to implement such a tax, as moves are being made on both the European and international level. The UK wants to be seen as an innovator by moving quickly, but it is taking the risk of being alone in a completely globalised digital market, as well as negatively impacting one of its key sectors ahead of its withdrawal from the European Union.The key for the UK tax to work will be international cooperation. The EU is pushing ahead with its own tax, spearheaded by France, but this has faced opposition. The US Treasury has said the proposals were unfair, while many tech companies, including European ones like Spotify , have also voiced concerns. Some member states which benefit from the current system are also against the plan, but the key country will be Germany, whose support has weakened in recent months. Without a wider agreement, the UK tax will have a limited impact. Investors And Employees Driven by their highly visible CSR obligations and a need to maintain brand integrity in an age where even a minor breach of trust can cause considerable public relations damage and impact share prices, consumer electronics vendors are becoming more careful about component sourcing. Devices use considerable quantities of rare earth metals, much of which is sourced from economically, socially and politically challenging markets, and they will be wary of being accused of exploiting local populations or helping corrupt regimes oppress their citizens and workers.'Conflict minerals' refer to the metals - namely tantalum, tin, tungsten, gold and cobalt - that are used in devices such as smartphones, TV sets and PCs but which are harvested from central African nations, including the Democratic Republic of Congo, Angola, Sudan, Uganda, Rwanda and the Central African Republic. These minerals are often the primary source of military funds of local armed rebels.High-profile vendors, such as Intel, Ericsson , Nokia and Samsung have established conflict-free minerals procurement policies that require suppliers to prioritise the use of conflict-free minerals in order to avoid indirect associated problems such as mistreatment of labourers, threatening workers with force, mass usage of child labour and destroyed ecology.Taiwan-based ASUS ' policy is typical of these high-profile brands, in that it requires its suppliers to reveal the status of procurement on conflict-free mineral every year. The rate of using conflict-free minerals by ASUS' supply chain had increased from 22% in 2013 to 97% by 2017 (latest published data). ASUS aims to source 100% of tantalum, tin, tungsten, gold and cobalt from qualified smelters by 2020.A relatively new aspect to this face of the puzzle is the growing influence of employees as a force of social conscience. Big tech companies have been supplying communications services to governments and their military forces for many years but, as technology has evolved to become more pervasive and sophisticated, so employees have become concerned that the companies they work for are putting profits ahead of ethics.Amazon, Google and Microsoft have been developing facial recognition software for use by the military and law enforcement organisations. Their employees - along with a number of advocacy groups - have called on the companies not to sell these artificial intelligence (AI)-powered systems to governments until they could ensure the technology could not be misused or employed for unethical reasons. Amazon has acknowledged that its Rekognition system could be used for unethical surveillance or population control, but is still pushing ahead with efforts to sell it to the US Federal Bureau of Investigation ( FBI). Amazon is also seeking to provide cloud services to the Department of Defense's cloud computing project, JEDI, despite the concerns of its employees. It is a deal worth USD10bn and would put Amazon ahead of rivals Google and Microsoft in the hotly contested cloud services market. urn:contentItem:5YJ8-6651-DXP9-902S-00000-00Sustainable businesses should be ‘long-term greedy’2019-03-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:39ZLexisNexisSustainable businesses should be ‘long-term greedy’Robert Armstrong

When economic historians look back at the present era in a century or two, they might struggle to make sense of the preponderance of a parti... When economic historians look back at the present era in a century or two, they might struggle to make sense of the preponderance of a particular word — one that captures...

When economic historians look back at the present era in a century or two, they might struggle to make sense of the preponderance of a parti... When economic historians look back at the present era in a century or two, they might struggle to make sense of the preponderance of a particular word — one that captures...

When economic historians look back at the present era in a century or two, they might struggle to make sense of the preponderance of a parti...

When economic historians look back at the present era in a century or two, they might struggle to make sense of the preponderance of a particular word — one that captures the preoccupations of businesspeople in the early 21st century but is devilishly hard to pin down. That word is “sustainability”.

Of course, we all have a general sense of what sustainability refers to. For most of the history of business, it was enough that a business made a profit. As the old phrase has it, the business of business is to stay in business. Sometime in the 20th century, however, the planet got a little more crowded and it became clear that the profit motive alone might not solve every resource allocation problem. It became evident that companies had better aim for something more than just returns on capital invested. A sustainable business is one delivering on that something.

What is it, then?

Part of the answer is about social responsibility: companies should be responsive to employees as well as shareholders, should not harm our common environment, should support civic life rather than enriching tyrants, and so on. But there is more to sustainability, I would argue, than collective responsibility. It is also about what kind of profit motive drives a business. Sustainable businesses are “long-term greedy”: they want to generate prosperity into the distant future, not make a quick buck. And they should create positive economic externalities, not extract economic rent.

Does this all sound a bit abstract? Perhaps, but happily the seven winners of this year’s FT ArcelorMittal Boldness in Business Awards provide concrete examples of what it means for a business to be sustainable in the fullest possible sense. And they show how sustainability in business requires intelligence, invention, courage and verve.

What is required for real sustainability is, in a word, boldness.

Let us start with one of the most straightforward forms of sustainability — the environmental one. Iceland Foods’ commitment to radically reduce — and eventually eliminate — both palm oil from its products and plastic from its packaging is admirable enough, considered in isolation. But it also dispels one of the most pernicious myths about environmental sustainability: that it is a luxury good to be indulged in only by well-to-do consumers and the top-shelf brands that cater to them. Iceland is a value brand, but it is also an excellent business that is in a good position to take responsibility for all the external costs its operations have the potential to create.

Others should follow its example. Bold leadership is not a luxury good, and this year’s award for corporate responsibility and environment recognises that.

One of the most unfortunate facts of human nature (what we now call a “cognitive bias”) is the tendency to see all business situations as zero-sum. “Think win-win,” we are told again and again, but the point never seems to sink in. A good definition of a sustainable business is one that makes whole commercial networks work better — enriching all the participants, rather than separating the winners from the losers.

This magic is found particularly in information businesses, and this year’s developing market award winner, Gro Intelligence, is an information business with immense potential. By gathering disparate sources of agricultural data, and doing the analytic work of turning the data into decision-making tools, it is set to make agriculture businesses more productive. A bold project the judges were pleased to endorse.

Next comes a gritty, literal sense of sustainability: the sheer ability to stick with it. Bold businesspeople cling to their long-term vision for their business, even when short-term conditions are unfriendly.

I was reminded of how hard it is for long-term-oriented businesses to stick to their guns by a comment that Warren Buffett made at a Berkshire Hathaway annual meeting. He was asked by an investor whether Berkshire’s ability to buy high-quality private businesses outright would be maintained when he no longer ran the company. Business owners, the questioner suggested, are drawn to the Buffett mystique.

These opportunities had nothing to do with him, Buffett replied: owners who want to sell their businesses, but want to ensure they will be managed for the long run, have nowhere else to go. Public markets, private equity and everything in between — we live in a short-term world.

Ocado, the recipient of this year’s technology award, has borne the full weight of the market’s short-termism and come out the other side. The company and its founders endured years of pummelling from the markets as sceptics argued that a sufficient number of grocers would not adopt its technology for automating warehouses to facilitate grocery delivery, and the company would remain subscale for ever. (Full disclosure: even the FT’s Lex column under my editorship sided with the sceptics. We were wrong.)

The company stuck to its vision and the customers did appear, in Europe and the US, sending the share price rocketing. At a moment when Britain needs a technology success story, Ocado is providing one.

Next, a somewhat paradoxical meaning of sustainability: the ability to change. Fast Retailing, winner of this year’s drivers of change award, has struck a remarkable balance between price and quality in its clothing. The products are inexpensive but not disposable, not meant to be worn for a season and thrown away, as many brands in the same price range are. Indeed, the quality matches that of many high-priced brands, and is forcing them to adapt.

Fast keeps the pressure on rivals by continuing to invest in technology and efficiency. Quality is maintained because underlying processes change.

One of the most reliable ways to win in business is to stay focused on serving a permanent and unchanging human need — especially when that requires doing things in a new way. There is no human desire more fundamental than that to eat ice cream. The entrepreneurship award this year was, for me, an easy choice. Halo Top, a business started in a lawyer’s kitchen, made a place for itself in a market dominated by big, entrenched brands by delivering a low-calorie, high-protein product that was just better. Sustainable businesses, at a basic level, do not simply ensure customers pay up. They make sure those customers are happy.

Of course, there may be needs that have not yet been satisfied at all, except in dreams: in a nod to this, the judges’ pick for small company was Lilium, which may deliver a low-noise, no-emission air taxi — or, as it is known to the child in all of us, a flying car. A business, or a world, that stops dreaming boldly becomes unsustainable fast, after all.

A final definition of sustainability is one that in my mind is the most important. Truly sustainable businesses — which, I have argued here, are all distinguished by their boldness of spirit — are operated with the recognition that some things are more important than business. There are values to which all commercial endeavours are subordinate.

Sir Tim Berners-Lee, our person of the year, saw how the internet, which he did so much to bring to life, was put to use for the exploitation of individuals rather than their liberation. His latest endeavour, Inrupt, is trying to redesign the web to change this, putting individuals back in charge of their own information.

The judges hope to look back, years into the future, and see that the businesses we have recognised in 2019 are still growing, innovating and striking out for new territory. Bold business is sustainable business.

Winners

Person of the Year: Sir Tim Berners-Lee
By designing the world wide web three decades ago, Sir Tim cemented himself as one of the most influential people of the modern era: his creation has had an incalculable impact on our everyday lives. But having grown increasingly concerned at how large interests were exploiting the web’s openness — including for electoral manipulation and cyber crime — the British computer scientist designed a data platform called Solid aimed at returning ownership of data to the users who generate it. In 2018, Sir Tim launched Inrupt, a for-profit company intended to put Solid into operation, maximising the upsides of the web while minimising its downsides. The goal, in Sir Tim’s words, is to “give people complete control of their data”.

Drivers of Change: Fast Retailing
The Japanese group, whose clothing brands include Theory, J Brand and Uniqlo, has grown to become the world’s third-largest casual clothing retailer. It is investing in technology to increase efficiencies: its automation of a Japanese distribution centre enabled 24-hour operations and increased productivity 80-fold. Fast Retailing is now investing nearly $1bn to automate its warehouse and distribution operations worldwide.

Corporate Responsibility/Environment: Iceland Foods
The UK retailer has long been committed to environmental campaigning, removing artificial colourings from its food in the 1980s and banning genetically modified ingredients in the 1990s. More recently, the company started two key environmental initiatives: to reduce plastic use within five years and to stop using palm oil in its own-brand products. Despite a television ban for its political content, Iceland’s Christmas ad about the impact of palm oil — featuring a homeless orangutan called Rang-Tan — received millions of views online.

Entrepreneurship: Halo Top
In 2011, Halo Top founder Justin Woolverton began experimenting in his kitchen to create an ice cream that satisfied his sweet tooth but contained substantially fewer calories than commercial brands. By the end of 2018, Halo Top had a hefty share of the North American market and was generating annual revenues of more than $300m. Halo Top has also started selling its low-calorie ice cream in the UK, Australia and Singapore, and continues to expand internationally.

Technology: Ocado
The UK online supermarket has evolved into a technology group by selling its warehousing and ecommerce system, the Ocado Smart Platform, to other grocery retailers. In Ocado’s warehouses, which are temperature-controlled to store fresh goods, robots collaborate to fetch goods and have the ability to complete a 50-item order in a few minutes. Since 2017, the company has signed deals with leading international retailers in Europe and North America.

Developing Markets: Gro Intelligence
Founded to provide agricultural data about Africa, Gro Intelligence has expanded to focus on global food markets. Its data help users better plan for droughts, invest in more resilient crops and make better-informed choices about loans and investments. Gro uses machine learning to model data such as future crop yields with high accuracy — recently the US Department of Agriculture revised down forecasts for US corn and soyabean production, bringing them closer to Gro’s predictions.

Smaller Company: Lilium
The German start-up is developing electric air taxis that will be low-noise, high-speed and emission-free. In 2017, the company completed a first test flight of its two-seater jet, which executed its signature transition from vertical to horizontal flight. The launch helped Lilium raise more than $100m in funding to develop the aircraft for commercial use. Lilium is aiming for its flying taxi service to be operational by 2025.

Other nominees

Drivers of Change

GW Pharmaceuticals
The UK medical group was approached in 2012 by the parents of an epileptic boy to see if its cannabis-based medicine could be developed as a treatment for his seizures. In 2018, the resulting drug, Epidiolex, was the first cannabis-based medication to be approved by the US Food and Drug Administration.

Inrupt
In 2018, Tim Berners-Lee, founder of the world wide web, launched Inrupt, to enable users to take control of their personal data from big tech. Instead of allowing online services to use their Facebook or Gmail accounts to access their details, Inrupt’s Solid helps users share that information themselves using a personal online data store.

Just
The US food technology company makes plant-based alternatives to animal products, including Just Mayo, an egg-free mayonnaise. The group has also launched Just Egg, a vegan product with the taste and texture of scrambled eggs.

Monzo
The UK digital bank was founded in 2015, aimed at providing financial services to people “who live their lives on their iPhones”. Monzo is constructing a marketplace where customers can access financial services provided by partner organisations. The company has raised £20m from 36,000 investors via crowdfunding and has more than 1m customers.

Revolution
AOL co-founder Steve Case started venture capital group Revolution, which since 2013 has invested in innovative US companies not based in New York or California. On his annual “Rise of the Rest” tour, Case visits start-ups across the US, and has raised more than $1bn to invest in them.

Corporate Responsibility / Environment

BlackRock
In 2018, the world’s largest asset manager announced its commitment to “sustainable investing” and launched exchange traded funds that prioritise social, environmental and governance factors. It estimates such ETFs will grow from $25bn to more than $400bn in the next decade.

Covestro
The German company makes a compound called cardyon, used to create foam for mattresses and furniture. It can produce up to 5,000 tonnes a year of the polymer, made with 20 per cent waste carbon dioxide.

Neighbourly
UK-based Neighbourly is an online platform that enables companies and individuals to donate food to local charities, helping UK retailers meet a commitment to reduce food waste by 20 per cent by 2025.

ReNew Power
A developer and operator of wind turbines and solar panels, ReNew is India’s largest clean energy producer. Last year it acquired Ostro Energy, and founder Sumant Sinha is eyeing more deals to consolidate India’s fragmented renewables industry.

Vindhya e-Infomedia
Two-thirds of the Indian outsourcer’s staff are disabled — unusual for a country where disabled people face significant discrimination. The provider of claims processing, payroll and data management has attracted clients such as IBM, Accenture and SAP, while staff turnover is in single digits.

Technology

Astroscale
The Japanese company was founded in 2013 to tackle the problems posed by the estimated 750,000 pieces of debris circling the earth in space. The company’s space mission ELSA-d, where a test launch will aim to capture a satellite, is scheduled for 2020.

BenevolentAI
The UK medical start-up uses artificial intelligence (AI) to mine and analyse biomedical data in an effort to discover compounds for development as new medical treatments.

Celonis
The German technology group’s AI-driven enterprise software analyses business processes. The software takes flows of information, such as those related to invoices or logistics, and visualises it in a way that makes inefficiencies easier to spot.

Darktrace
The UK cyber security company’s Enterprise Immune System uses unsupervised machine learning that can establish a baseline of normal activity for any computer network and identify threats, much like the human immune system. Darktrace was valued at $1.65bn in September 2018.

Oxitec
The UK biotechnology company has genetically modified mosquitoes to prevent their offspring reaching adulthood. In May 2018, Oxitec launched a pilot project in the Cayman Islands and has received funding from the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation.

Entrepreneurship

Bulb Energy
The company was founded in 2015 to offer renewable energy without the hefty premium charged by rivals. Having raised £60m of funding, it aims to supply 5m UK households within five years.

Fever-Tree
The UK-based soft drinks company produces high-quality mixers. Since launching its first tonic water in 2005, it has developed a wide range and overtook Schweppes as the UK’s leading mixer supplier in 2017.

Mercari
The Japanese start-up is an app-based marketplace that enables consumers to sell second-hand goods to one another. It became Japan’s first start-up to be valued at more than $1bn, with 30 per cent of Japan’s population using the service.

Modanisa
Turkish entrepreneur Kerim Ture founded Modanisa in 2011 to fill a gap in the online market for Muslim women looking for modest but fashionable clothing. It sells more than 70,000 products from 500 brands.

Revolut
The financial services app offers its mostly European users international money transfers, cryptocurrency trading and fee-free currency exchange at the interbank exchange rate. The London-based company had a customer base of 2.8m by the end of 2018, and is expanding into the US and Asia.

Developing Markets

BYJU’s
India’s largest educational tech company offers app-based learning programmes and test preparation to primary and secondary school pupils. In September 2018 it received a $100m investment for a 5 per cent stake, which it plans to use to expand internationally.

CargoX
The Brazilian company’s platform connects companies needing to ship goods with trucks with spare capacity. CargoX expects to reach $1bn in revenue by 2021 and plans to bring the technology to a wider global market.

Tala
Launched in Kenya in 2014, Tala’s app offers microfinance loans in emerging markets, using data points from a user’s smartphone to assist lending decisions. By October 2018, the company had issued more than $500m in loans, and raised funding from PayPal to expand globally.

Transsion
The Chinese electronics company makes smartphones aimed at sub-Saharan African consumers. It has adapted to that market by improving battery life, enabling phones to house multiple SIM cards, and recognise local languages.

Ualá
The Argentine fintech company’s personal finance app is linked to a Mastercard prepaid card. Its widespread adoption is encouraging cash-reliant Argentines to switch to digital banking. Goldman Sachs led a $34m funding round for the group in 2018.

Smaller Company

American Giant
Retailing entirely online, the clothing company was founded with hopes of regenerating the US garment-making industry. The company has gained popularity on the back of the “Made in America” movement.

Goonhilly Earth Station
Once the world’s largest satellite station, the site in south-west England provides telecoms and satellite-tracking services. It is upgrading its antennas to meet deep-space communication requirements, which will enable Goonhilly to communicate with missions to Mars or the Moon by 2020.

Icon
The Texan construction tech group was founded to develop tools capable of 3D-printing housing, to lower the time and cost of construction. In 2018, Icon unveiled the first home built to US regulations by the company’s 3D printer, Vulcan; it took 48 hours to print the 350 sq ft building and cost $10,000.

Isabel Healthcare
The UK company’s software matches users’ descriptions of symptoms to clinical terms, enabling doctors and patients to identify the disease.

Science 37
The US-based company enables pharmaceutical companies to decentralise their medical research by conducting clinical trials via smartphones. Patients use their phone to record results and interact with researchers.
